Warning: long comment! TL;DR: music is fun and educational! Try as many different kinds of music as you're unfamiliar with. Go outside your comfort zone. :-)

I grew up in the '70's, surrounded by Country and later, Hip-Hip, neither of which I got into, though I still like individual songs from both groups. Later Rap got more interesting to me, but I still didn't truly get into it--again, just a few pieces caught my interest and I still like them. Early Metal was really popular in my area, too (Black Sabbath, Metallica, etc), and that seemed to be it for musical styles except for some '60's and '70's Classic Rock, and a little Top 40. Really limited. So, I got tired of most of that pretty quickly, and got into New Wave, Goth/Industrial, Death Metal, Punk, and various types of World Music I found at this one shop I frequented that had an eclectic music-section. Found all kinds of cool stuff there.

For an example, give Balinese Gamelan a try--you'll either love it, or hate it. It uses odd, trembling tones throughout the style, where instruments are deliberately tuned and played ever-so-slightly out of step with each other to form an overall throbbing sort of effect. Crazy stuff. Or Hungarian folk-singing. Eerie as heck, but gorgeous. Same with Finnish folk-music. Some really unexpected tonal-changes that raise the hairs on your arms. The Finnish stuff will likely be more accessible for Western ears than the Gamelan, since it still uses a standard 8 octave scale and they use instruments we're more familiar with, like violin and guitar. They just use it in ways my untrained ear never expects!

I think a person can have Perfect Pitch and not know what the names of the notes are. They just can call them maybe "flat" or "sharp", just based on their effect, but without knowing the conventions in Western music, knowing the names wouldn't be automatic. In that sense, if Perfect Pitch only meant you knew what note is what, seemingly flawlessly, then I think it *could* be taught. But, there's more to Perfect Pitch than knowing the names of the notes. I think of Perfect Pitch as being able to accurately *replicate* the notes one hears, not just naming them.

The names are a system that's entirely separate from the sounds, and is a Western European fabrication, one that other World systems of music don't always use, unless they're trying to transcribe their pieces into Standardized Musical Staff. That gets to be a lot of frustration--and fun--for ethnic musicians who's traditional scales use a lot of half-steps, quarter-steps, or are sliding scales that don't "settle" at all. I don't see how having Perfect Pitch means you'll auto-magically be able to name that note as an "A", for example, if you're not *already* familiar with the naming system and how it works.

I'm not a trained musician, and cannot read musical staff. I also didn't know the names of the notes until I took choir in high-school; even then, I didn't learn to read the staffs because we weren't actually taught that part. I learned everything by ear, and our teacher found my voice thin, but trainable, and he liked that I had a both wide range and very good pitch, so he had a habit of assigning me the more complicated parts of the songs we did. To this day, I despise "The Flowers of Her Face", a jazz (I think?) piece I had real trouble wrapping my brain around, because of that. LOL I don't believe I have perfect pitch, though it's really evident to me when a note is "off". I was able to name the tones you guys played in the video, but I think only because I'd heard them labeled before.

I have synesthesia, where for me, colours have "sounds", and vice versa. So, having an interesting variety of music to choose from can be a mental treat for me--I get to watch in my mind's eye swirls and blobs, flashes and streaks of colour as the music plays. Having different genre interests helps, too: I need variety, or I'll get bored easily. It's one reason why I grew to dislike most popular stuff on the radio--it got played too often while the music-producers were trying to sell it as the next greatest thing. Doesn't stop me from glomming onto a neat piece of so-called "Popular" music, though. Some recent ones that probably got way too much airplay are "Despocito" and "Shape of You", but I still like those two because of how different they are from what I associate with "Pop" music.

When I was learning piano, my dad hated classical "long hair" music. One day, I was practicing a piece. He stood behind and slightly above me, watching my hands. After I finished the piece, he told me it was the most beautiful music he had ever heard. He was actually crying (he never cried)l He said he had never seen anyone's fingers move so quickly and the piece made him actually feel like he was next to a stream listening to the water. He actually started listening to classical music on his car radio and on the radio in his office. He "borrowed" (permanently) several tapes of mine. All he had ever listened to was country from the 50's and some rock from the same era. Before he died, he converted his wife to the same kind of music. Strange huh? A parent changed his taste in music because of his kids. He loved Mozart, Beethoven and his absolute favorite songs was Gershwin's "Rhapsody in Blue" and the Beethoven "Moonlight Sonata". Bach moved him also. He started listening because of the MASH episode where Radar was told to say "Ah Bach".

I don't have this kind of reaction, but some songs can bring uncontrollable tears of joy - such as Waltz of the Flowers.

Eargasms I get from studio recordings often make it nearly impossible for me to enjoy the same songs played live in concert, because the artists never play them exactly the same way live as they did in the studio, and I'm disappointed when I don't hear my expected "eargasm hooks". But if the artists change the style of the songs completely, say from Hard Rock to Unplugged, I can listen to them with "fresh ears" and enjoy them on their own merits. My favourite example is the original "Layla" (loaded with eargasms for me) vs. the unplugged version (no eargasms at all, but I still love it). 😊

Animals make their own music. Never mind whale songs or parrots, but when you hear wolves howling in the forest, they certainly sound as if they are singing to one another, and occasionally singing in harmony. I've found myself to experience the "Mere Exposure Effect" multiple times and it still shocks me. I do take the time to listen to a tune but if it doesn't resonate with me right away, I just move on and forget about it. My taste in music has changed over the years, from me not feeling the same way with my favorite songs and enjoying songs that I previously did like. Also, after listening to epic, orchestral and classical music while studying, I found that I can no longer hear instrumental music in movies as simply a background. I can study with similar music just fine, but when I am watching a moving with moving music, I am promoted to focus on the music instead of the current scene, which probably is not the intention of the background music. This was really interesting video, thank you SciShow for sharing the knowledge on why we like music!

First add sand to the plate then begin playing a tone. Certain frequencies vibrate the metal plate in such a way that it creates areas where there is no vibration. The sand "falls" into those areas, creating beautiful geometric patterns. As the frequency increases in pitch the patterns become more complex.

Incredible UV Sand Resonance Experiment!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hIgmiDnmVdU

The frequency is the number of waves that pass a point in space during any time interval, usually one second. We measure it in units of cycles (waves) per second, or hertz. The frequency of visible light is referred to as color, and ranges from 430 trillion hertz, seen as red, to 750 trillion hertz, seen as violet.

Materials don't have resonant frequencies. They have bulk properties which affect the resonance of suitable structures (e.g. a tuning fork) made out of them. The frequency of a given structure made from different materials depends on the mass density and stiffness (bulk) properties of the material.

It's interesting that we are trying to use science to explain something that is emotional and ethereal because it lacks the language and vocabulary to convey anything meaningful about what it is to appreciate and feel a song. Having an eargasm is all about context, attention, and your ability to get lost in a song. When a song takes you outside of your own head, and puts you into a world that only exists in your imagination as you hear the song, the music can elate you and lift you up like you're the king of the world. Queen has a catalog of music almost scientifically designed to lift you on high. We are the champions, Don't stop me now, Bohemian Rhapsody, even the theme song to Flash Gordon, all make your hair stand on end when you really get into them.

Regarding Earworms: If I listen to a song where I know all or some of the lyrics and don't finish the song or am interrupted whilst listening to it, it becomes an earworm. And the only way to get rid of said earworm is to listen to that song *without getting interrupted*. And I need to finish that song. Sometimes I need to listen to that song on repeat to eventually get rid of it.

It's a unique language and expression of all we are in most ways possible. Easy to understand, hard to explain technically. Anything you want to express with any range in any order with any thing, like anything else or as different from anything. You are a person and you are this or that until you do something else and even so far as you can perform as a human it matches whatever shape that may take and it disappears into the air, but we remember and feel how it works in our brains simplistically or complex with a diversity of activity that can't always be matched or activated with whatever else is around us, but it can also match that should we want it to. Music is like language with diversity free from the constriction of definition or as rigidly defined as you want.

I wanted to say that just because an animal or a person prefer silence to music, doesn't mean they don't like music, rather they need to be able to hear predators and have their fight or flight senses at the ready at all times. So in that sense, I think that study is flawed.
at about 15:30 when talking about animals and music, I was reminded of a study decades ago that said cows gave more milk while listening to the classics than they did when listening to rock and roll.
